NCEA Endorsements Explained
What is an Endorsement?An endorsement is a way to recognise when you do really well in a subject or across a whole NCEA level. It shows that you didn’t just pass — you did it with merit or excellence. There are two main types of endorsements: 1. Certificate Endorsement (for your overall NCEA level) 2. Course (or Subject) Endorsement (for individual subjects)

1. Certificate EndorsementThis is for your whole NCEA Level 1, 2, or 3 certificate. To get your certificate endorsed with Merit or Excellence, you need:
  • At least 50 credits at Merit (for Merit Endorsement)
  • OR at least 50 credits at Excellence (for Excellence Endorsement)
Note: The credits can come from any subjects at that NCEA level (or above). Example: If you’re in Year 11 and earn 52 credits at Excellence in total across all your subjects, your Level 1 Certificate will be Endorsed with Excellence.

2. Course (Subject) EndorsementThis is for doing well in a specific subject in one year (like English or Science). To get a Course Endorsement, you need:
  • 14 or more credits in that subject at Merit or Excellence
  • At least 3 credits from internal assessmentsM/li>
  • At least 3 credits from external assessments
(Some subjects like PE or Art may not have external exams — that’s okay; NZQA makes exceptions.) Example: If you get 16 credits in Level 1 Science with 10 from internal assessments and 6 from external exams, and 14 of those credits are at Excellence, you’ll get a Course Endorsement with Excellence in Science.

Why Do Endorsements Matter?
  • They show you're performing above the standard.
  • They look great on your school reports and future applications (e.g., university, scholarships, jobs).
  • They’re a good personal goal if you want to challenge yourself.
